number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I've only dinked around with a few guitars over the years. I ultimately have very little idea what I'm actually doing with the guitar (save a few chords and memorized riffs here and there). Pure noob.When I first heard about the concept of Rocksmith years ago I was very interested in the idea of a Guitar Hero or Rock Band type game that you actually played a real guitar. (I was a huge fan of those games.) The problem...I didn't know how to actually play a real guitar. Could it be possible that a game like Rocksmith could teach me to really play? The verdict went out, most reviews and videos I watched came back ecstatic about Rocksmith being not only a game, but a fantasic teaching tool as well. The only downsides I caught wind of were a horribly designed interface, some sound interface and gain issues. Alas I decided to hold off and moved on never purchasing the 'original Rocksmith' game.Then came Rocksmith 2014. The same excitement bubbled up within me about a life long desire to teach myself guitar and play some of my favorite rock songs I've been listening to over the years. But would the game have fixed it minor short comings from the prior release? The reviews came in ....fantastic, 10/10, 5 stars, 9.5/10 etc.etc. Wow. They got it right and what's more they seemed to have greatly improved not only the interface, but the whole game experience itself. From the in game arcade where you can hone your guitar techniques that many guitar instructors teach in their lessons. To a great lesson section in which all the techniques and terminologies are carefully and skillfully delivered to those who need them, along with a practice session that increases the difficulty as you perform the lesson better. Then (of coarse) the actual learning of a song. Wow. Super fun. The problem with the real guitar lessons that my friends and other took is that they plateaued and grew bored with their slow progress and lame nursery songs for beginners. Rocksmith masterfully throws that old paradigm out the window and allows the player to learn their favorite songs, but at the level it detects the user can handle. Then it slowly increases the skill level as you master more perfectly the notes/chords that are launched your way. It is fun, motivational, and very progressive. Your skill will increase in just the first few weeks alone.The game also includes and virtual band called Session Mode where you can play with your own band that you define and calibrate then play with. They adjust to your key/chord progession, tempo, style...etc.  Just another of many wows within the game. This game is a gem and has found it's place in my heart.Ubisoft it seems has fully embraced the notion that a game like Rocksmith is equally used as a learning tool to learn from scratch how to play the electric/rythem/bass guitars, or the hone your skills even if your a guitar shredding vet. Both types seem to be happy with what Ubisoft has delivered this run.Their are of coarse a good selection of tracks included with the game itself. Or they are always adding to the growing library of DLC songs or song packs to more greatly expand your library of favorite guitar songs/licks/riffs etc.I haven't played a game where I was actually learning something that truly had a place and meaning outside of the gaming world. What a breathe of fresh air. They are trailblazing a new type of genre in effect. Not just the guitar playing genre, but the learning a real skill game genre. (lame name, but you get it.  :P  )Very excited about this one. It's just different in all the right ways from anything else out there. Try it, find out for yourself.-GooseSwan

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Excellent software for practicing guitar and bass (pronounced /bās/), it's like having your very own practice coach in your computer!It's more of a tool for honing your guitar skills than an actual game, though the original Rocksmith was more of a game than this version is. It needs to be coupled with other material to give you music theory, but it does try to cover some of this itself. If you are just interested in playing with little care towards learning to play outside of Rocksmith, then it's certainly completely capable of providing an experience like that without having to learn anything more than what Rocksmith 2014 can teach you.But if you treat Rocksmith 2014 as a practice coach and find yourself a good theory coach, then you can fully expect at some point to be playing music outside of the game with relative ease. I've found a good place to start in getting that theory coaching is the Hal Leonard FastTrack Guitar (or Bass)  Method Starter Pack that includes a book, CD & DVD. It can be had for under $15 and covers the basics fairly succinctly.But like in the old joke "How do you get to Carnegy Hall?", the answer is "practice!", and that's what Rocksmith 2014 really brings to the table. It coaches you on new techniques and ramps up the difficulty as you get better at playing, but it provides an interactive environment that stimulates you and challenges you WHILE you get in that all so important practice time. It deals with the single biggest barrier to becoming musically adept, namely the 'grind'. You may never get to Carnegy Hall, but with Rocksmith 2014 practicing is no longer a drudge!If you intend to play songs outside of Rocksmith then you may want to invert the view of the strings on the screen, putting the low E on the bottom to match the way tab is written. Once you are used to this orientation, then downloading guitar songs that are notated in tab will afford you the ability to play them without having to mentally flip what you see on the paper because you avoided instilling bad habits while using Rocksmith by orienting the display to match the way tab is written from the start. Of course, if you never intend to play music outside of Rocksmith then it shouldn't matter...Multiplayer is pretty fun, though very basic in how it's done in Rocksmith. You can play any combination of guitar and bass, including emulated bass in multiplayer. If you haven't given this a try, you should! Multiplayer uses two separate profiles under the same account, we played at my friend's house so I had to start a profile under his account to do this. While I could also use this profile in single player, it's under his account and not mine so I can only use it when he's the one logged in. There doesn't seem to be a way to use my main profile under my account while we are logged in on his system, so any progress I make under the profile I use on his account is lost except when I'm playing multiplayer. Playing emulated bass is pretty fun by itself, but doesn't hold a candle to playing with a real 4-string bass! It's worth the money to go to the local pawn shop and buy a used Ibanez GSR100 or Dean Edge 9 bass for under $100. Like the BC Rich Bronze Series Warlock, most pawn shops have these around and usually for less than $100, though any Silvertone, Jay Turser, SX, Gregg Bennett, Squier, etc.  guitar or bass can be had at a pawn shop for less than $100 are all well worth the cost and enhances the Rocksmith experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Having a guitar sitting around for a year or so now, I decided to pick this game up to actually learn it. I was surprised at how much I actually learned just in the first day. In fact, you learn almost everything you need to know about guitar in Rocksmith that you need in order to play. The problem arises in the ways in which you are able to practice. As I suspected, the game is riddled with connectivity issues between the game and the guitar you are using between the Real Tone cable. Being a former 'professional' Guitar Hero player myself, I was afraid that the mini-games would be pretty much unplayable, and I was right. Sometimes strumming the correct note will result in a miss, and if strummed hard enough, you can actually strum any note, and the game will classify it as the correct note. Overall, I would still highly recommend picking up Rocksmith if you want to learn guitar. But I would advise staying away from it if you want to use it to practice.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5
												A lot of people are probably going to be confused at why i have so many hours logged in this game yet im giving it a not reccomended rating, the main reason for that is because i have more been using this game as a makeshift amplifier, rather than the way it was intended. This game is a great way to learn how to play to an extent.  and this review is based on my personal experiences. this is not my reccomendation for your primary go to way of learning how to play Here is why:1. the game is designed around a notes or tablature style of learning and when you are playing individual notes, it doesnt tell you what the name of the note actually is, this is really troublesome if you are planning to use this program to learn to play the bass guitar. you really should learn at least a few scales before you start to just play songs.2. you get so used to playing the songs that you do learn to the backing tracks provided. i will explain why this is a problem after point number three.3. the game actually makes it sound like you are playing than you actually are, and often times you can just hit random notes during a guitar solo of a song and at least get a good enough portion of it recognized as right that the game still gives you a good rating on that section.  the reason that these two are a problem is that when you go to play a song that you think you learned and think that you can play outside the game, be it showing off your newfound skill to friends or just jamming at a guitar store, you will instantly realize that you have no idea what you are doing and that you have been learning the wrong thing the whole time.that said, the game is good i would say for those that already have some prior knowledge of how to play a guitar as it does give you a real time look at what notes are played where if you know your fretboard well enough already.  if you actually are looking to learn to play the guitar or bass, i suggest your best option is to invest in an actual music tutor.  that way you learn the right way first.  it may be more expensive that way, but it puts you better off in the long run.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Rocksmith 2014 neatly combines Game aspects along with Teaching aspects. Viewed as a game, it's solid--there are achievements, a very smooth difficulty curve with the game adjusting to your abilities on the fly, feedback, and a proper sense of progress.  Viewed as a guitar (and bass) tutor, it's excellent. The UI is well done, with intuitive controls.  There is no noticeable lag, and the hardware (a usb to 1/4inch jack dongle) is solid.  My guitar is a junk fender strat clone, but works well with the game.There is a large amount of DLC too. Pity it's never on sale!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												The Ubisoft guys did a nice job on this version.  I previously had the Xbox version, and I hated playing on my console through a TV.  The HDMI lag was not great.  With Rocksmith 2014, I bought the Steam version, installed in on the Mac i use for music work, and have it running through my studio setup.  Makes all the difference in the world.  Zero lag, great sound.Improvements this version include a session mode, where you pick a key and some band members, and they just sort of follow along with you.  While they arent the best backing band, it does give you an opportunity to practice scales and riffs with a rythm section behind you.  Another improvement is that it seems to more accurately catch what you are playing, shift difficulty at more appropriate times and the riff repeater is superb for really learning a part.  You get a ton of control over when it ups the difficulty (or whether it does) and speed.I've been playing guitar, rythm, lead and bass, for over 30 years now, and I can honestly say that while I thought this was going to be a toy, ala rockband, I have definitely increased my skill by playing it.  At first I dismissed the guitarcade as a gimmick, but it definitely has made my scales faster, and my accuracy and fretboard position awareness significantly better.The only complaints I have are:  1. I wish riff repeater was slightly more controllable as to when it starts and stop instead of being such large sections.  There have been a couple times where I was trying to learn a tough little flourish that occurs at the end of an easy section, and had to play the easy section over and over to get to the short riff because i couldnt shorten the RR selection enough.  That said, I got really good at it :)2. The instructions for getting the Rocksmith 1 content should have been clearer.  I did finally get it to work, but I shouldn't have had to go to the forums for answers, that should have been a simple step by step process with rock solid documentation.Overall I give it a 9/10.  Great tool for learning, and even for those of us with lots of experience there is a lot of learning to do.  It still amazes me when you spend 10 minutes on it, and suddenly pick up a tricky section as they throw it at you seemingly out of the blue at times.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Excellent software for practicing guitar and bass (pronounced /bās/), it's like having your very own practice coach in your computer!It's more of a tool for honing your guitar skills than an actual game, though the original Rocksmith was more of a game than this version is. It needs to be coupled with other material to give you music theory, but it does try to cover some of this itself. If you are just interested in playing with little care towards learning to play outside of Rocksmith, then it's certainly completely capable of providing an experience like that without having to learn anything more than what Rocksmith 2014 can teach you.But if you treat Rocksmith 2014 as a practice coach and find yourself a good theory coach, then you can fully expect at some point to be playing music outside of the game with relative ease. I've found a good place to start in getting that theory coaching is the Hal Leonard FastTrack Guitar (or Bass)  Method Starter Pack that includes a book, CD & DVD. It can be had for under $15 and covers the basics fairly succinctly.But like in the old joke "How do you get to Carnegy Hall?", the answer is "practice!", and that's what Rocksmith 2014 really brings to the table. It coaches you on new techniques and ramps up the difficulty as you get better at playing, but it provides an interactive environment that stimulates you and challenges you WHILE you get in that all so important practice time. It deals with the single biggest barrier to becoming musically adept, namely the 'grind'. You may never get to Carnegy Hall, but with Rocksmith 2014 practicing is no longer a drudge!If you intend to play songs outside of Rocksmith then you may want to invert the view of the strings on the screen, putting the low E on the bottom to match the way tab is written. Once you are used to this orientation, then downloading guitar songs that are notated in tab will afford you the ability to play them without having to mentally flip what you see on the paper because you avoided instilling bad habits while using Rocksmith by orienting the display to match the way tab is written from the start. Of course, if you never intend to play music outside of Rocksmith then it shouldn't matter...Multiplayer is pretty fun, though very basic in how it's done in Rocksmith. You can play any combination of guitar and bass, including emulated bass in multiplayer. If you haven't given this a try, you should! Multiplayer uses two separate profiles under the same account, we played at my friend's house so I had to start a profile under his account to do this. While I could also use this profile in single player, it's under his account and not mine so I can only use it when he's the one logged in. There doesn't seem to be a way to use my main profile under my account while we are logged in on his system, so any progress I make under the profile I use on his account is lost except when I'm playing multiplayer. Playing emulated bass is pretty fun by itself, but doesn't hold a candle to playing with a real 4-string bass! It's worth the money to go to the local pawn shop and buy a used Ibanez GSR100 or Dean Edge 9 bass for under $100. Like the BC Rich Bronze Series Warlock, most pawn shops have these around and usually for less than $100, though any Silvertone, Jay Turser, SX, Gregg Bennett, Squier, etc.  guitar or bass can be had at a pawn shop for less than $100 are all well worth the cost and enhances the Rocksmith experience.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I've been playing guitar on and off for some years now and what I find the most disheartening after a long break is returning to the instrument and experiencing skill decay from the lack of practise. This is where Rocksmith 2014 comes in! If it were not for my puny callus-less fingers, I'd probably spend all day practising riffs, revising chords and working on general technique. The game keeps track of my progress and keeps throwing new stuff to do in my face. And before you know it a couple of hours have passed. Always new goals and song specific advice. I get to start out softly with a new song and I have different tools for learning the full versions at my own pace. I simply don't notice how much I am flubbing around because the game keeps me focused on progress and goals.There's also a bunch of the mini games I haven't tried yet, but I can see many nice additions since the first edition of Rocksmith. The session mode is also a decent addition, in that you get to use all your hard earned skills more freely with backing instruments.I find that the main draw of RS2014 is the motivational aspect, it gets you playing, it gets you practising. The game is not a replacement for a music teacher, since it cannot correct bad finger placement or perfectly detect the notes you play each time. It also lacks things in the music theory department, but you can find supplemental resources online easily these days. Maybe in ten years time, when the technology is there, we'll have a perfect artificial guitar teacher in RS. The current RS2014 is one of the better education games out there, I'd say.

Lessons are meh, mini games are very simple and also get stale fast. The bread and butter is the learn a song section and the session mode. Session mode lets you jam out with background instruments and tempo that you select, works well. Both good, except now with remastered update my 400 song roster is only 35 songs. Thanks Ubi, I sincerely hope whoever was responsible for that gets herpes. So unless the community comes up with a workaround for cdlc, or you have over 2,000$ laying around for dlc, pass on this. What a shame, broke a great game, just so they could try to gouge us with more overpriced dlc. If/when the community finds a fix for cdlc, then by all means, this is a great guitar learning aid and a ton of fun, buy it. 0/10, feel like a kid who had his toys set on fire in the driveway on christmas and had to watch them burn. Edit- since a fix is out, and my cdlc works now, I can recommend the game again! Seriously though, if you pick this up go to custom forge and download the songs you want. 												I never knew how to play the guitar until the first Rocksmith came out. After buying the game and a cheap guitar i found myself spending contless hours and had to buy  RS2014 as soon as it came out!! Continuing my journey to master the guitar (i hope i'll master it soon, although i've pogressed massively in the last 5 years).  I played through pretty much most of the songs and spent around £40 on dlc on the PS4. (Back when i was a console peasant, still occasionally play it) I bought my pc and noticed it was on sale here on steam and could not resist buying it again for the CDLC's which has been an absolute joy to play along to. I've ALMOST mastered Bury Tomorrow's; Man on fire with a few more notes to learn on the guitar solo and then i would have completed my goal in 2 weeks. (I did not set myself a deadline). If you just stick at it for even 30 minutes a day, you'll find yourself playing the guitar much quicker than a session here or there. You need to be determined and accept that you'll make 100's, 1,000's of mistakes to make any progress otherwise you might as well not bother. If it had not been for Rocksmith, i don't think i would have ever thought about playing the guitar. I know you can't communicate to your fellow members on discord while playing Rocksmith, but i'm not bothered as i make much more progress just concentrating on learning new songs on the guitar. One of the best purchases i have ever made was buying Rocksmith/Rocksmith2014.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												Short version: Yes you should buy it, yes it's worth it over Rocksmith 1. Rocksmith 2014 makes Rocksmith 1 look like an alpha. It's like they took all the small things that were bad in Rocksmith 1 (algorithm could ramp difficulty incorrectly, practice mode was outside of the song, "story mode" was dumb as all hell, visually sort of so-so, not very exciting) and irons them all out.You can play all your Rocksmith 1 DLC on 2014. All Rocksmith 1 DLC is available on 2014, with some arrangement changes to take advantage of some of the different techniques in 2014.The difficulty ramping algorithm is a hell of a lot better now, so it doesn't suddenly throw chords at you in the middle of nowhere like Rocksmith 1. You can hit the riff repeater INSIDE the song now to just practice a certain phrase, without having to go into a separate area. When you're done with it, you can hop back into the song where you left off. It's also got a breakdown of a song and the game detects areas you're struggling and suggests different lessons or games specific to the track you're working on. Missions guide you along to areas you need to work on, which gives you some direction if you're looking to improve. The game basically figures out which things you're good at at which you suck at, and recommends tracks that utilize those techniques to make you better.The game looks better visually and the frets are labelled as well as the fingers, making it easier to use. Purely visual, but when you practice now, you're basically inside a concrete practice room but as you improve your phrases a sort of "portal" appears on the wall where the notes are coming from which slowly widens to reveal a stage with a crowd. Nice effect--as you improve a song, more and more of the audience, lighting, and effects are revealed until you're basically on stage at 100%If you never played Rocksmith 1 but want to learn to play--you won't develop this really deep understanding of musical theory or anything from it, but you'll know enough to be able to pick up a guitar and play some tracks, as well as casually jam with people (if you remember your chords). Plus, lessons from a person are like $20 a pop, so this will pay for itself easily.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												I wouldn't call this this a game, it's far to deep into music to be that.Technique, chord and  scale lessons nicely back up around learning the songs themself, you even get suggestions on which part of the song or technique you should practice more on.At the end you play the songs completely without any tabs shown, but only when Rocksmith figures you can master it.It does not teach you theory, but that is always something people can study by googling it's different parts up.The only downside for someone who played guitar for years is that you only get single notes instead of the full chords when you start on a new song.There should have been an option labeled "show me everything".Quartermine's suggestion below fixes that to some extend.With that I mean, when you play loose notes over chord you usually have the chord written as well as the loose notes in pick order, Rocksmith misses out on the chord part.I usually just have to see the chord, then I know how to place my fingers and can easy hear in which order I have to pick them notes, RS kind of dumps it down to just being notes :DThe game misses out a few notes when it comest to solos and some loose notes in between riffs.Quite easy to hear and find them as a musician, but I guess that if your hearing isn't trained it can probably be of some annoiance.I did read some negative reviews regarding the game, and want to address a few of the things that people write in them.1. The guitar sound that you hear does require that you have at least a descent guitar, that does not mean expensive though.My cheapest guitar which is an Epiphone LP AFR does sound fine on mainly all songs.None of the videos that I heard on Youtube sound like that they are edited.I use mainly guitars with Humbuckers, some songs sound better with Single Coil pickups though.You might want to switch pickup positions and adjust on the volume and tone knob, a guitar is not something that you plug in and play by having everything at max.2. The USB cable is available trough Amazon, so it's not hard to find, although, I found it easyer to buy the game as a boxed version and then register it on Steam.3. There are no issues with buying songs and songpacks when you registred the game on Steam.4. If you bought Rocksmith 2014 and thought that it is just a game.... maybe check up a bit around what you buy before buying.5. You can probably cheat your way through some of the easy songs, but try to cheat your way through to a song like Pantera's Domination while playing as lead, good luck with that.6. Latency issues, there are no such issues, it works like any other ASIO USB driven sound interface, you do need to adjust for latency via Rocksmiths Audio menu.Also make sure to align the USB input with your soundcards output, 16bit and  either 44100 or 48000 Hz on both.If you still have issues, sorry to say so but something on your computer sucks in such case.

Posted: December 24, 2015
												While the game itself is a wonderful learning tool and fantastically fun for beginners and experienced guitarists, I cannot recommend the pc version of this game due to the windows drivers issues that many people including myself have. The USB cord for the guitar should a simple process of plugging it in to a USB port and once the drivers are downloaded, they will be saved and remembered the next time you plug and play. Instead the drivers are reinstalled everytime you reinsert the USB cable. Sometimes the driver downloads as it's suppose to as "Rocksmith USB device" but more often than not it downloads "USB Audio Device" which will not work, or even worse just "hocksmit" which does not work. I purchased a ton of the DLC songs hoping to add some songs I can learn to only find that the game has become unplayable after hours of trying to reconnect the device to get the correct usb driver. PLEASE create a driver which we can downloaded instead of the automatic driver detection ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. I relize that it is probably Windows at fault on this issue but if that's the case, cut them out and provide an easy solution to all those who have purchase your game for PC.

												Ever have you thought to yourself while watching or listening to your favourite band & thought to yourself "i would love to play a guitar just like them", Well with a game like this you can. Rocksmith gives you one of the best learning experience  i've ever played. For me learning a guitar was pretty hard, having to read everything from books & practice. But with rocksmith it teaches you everything you need to know, from bending to slides to pull off & such. With other games though it does have its problems.Good things:You do actually learn how to play.Easy tutorials - The tutorials in the game teach you everything you need to know at a slow pace.Advancing difficulty - As you play a song it will gradually get harder & harder the better you do & will get easier if your'e doing bad.Song list - There are quite alot of songs to pick from but at the same time, for an extra £7.99 you can import all of the first rocksmiths songs.Built in Tunner - Its nice to have a tunner built into the game but it has its problems.Mini Games - There are quite alot of mini games to play which will improve your skills. There fun too.Bad things:I haven't really come across that many bad things about thins game, but i have seen a few.Tunner - The tunner in the game is a challenge, it will tell you what note to tune your string to but when you play it back the game says its wrong. An easy fix is to turn your speakers off when your'e tunning, it really helps.Precision - The game will not give you a free pass, which sounds good but sometimes the game picks up notes i'm not even playing & bending has to be perfect or else the game won't allow it.More modern music - My type of music might be different from others (Metal of course) but i wold like to see more up to date music. Dont get me wrong, some of the songs in game are fun to plat & listen too but i would like to see more modern music.Thats all i can basically say about this game, it is so much fun & will get you playing a guitar in no time. It is definitionally worth the asking price & if your'e serious about wanting to play a guitar i would get it.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This is the perfect companion for learning to play! You learn the fundamentals the fun way, (something that can't be said about many instructional alternatives). And as for learning the songs, this Rocksmith surpasses the former by making sure you learn and recall sections by heart before you haphazardly continue, they even ocassionaly remove note annotations when they are certain you can play without further instruction (aka Master Mode). The menu can be tricky at times and one might find that editing particular functions can take a little bit longer and can be a tad confusing, but that shouldn't be an issue for most users. All in all, I highly recommend this to anyone, whether the person is already familiar with their instrument or simply starting out.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												About an hour in and I can see that this is a vast improvement over Rocksmith, which I poured over on 360 and then dabbled on PC.  The menus are snappy, and you can infinitely practice a song section however you like.    One of the reasons why I dropped off the first game was that it did a pour job of teaching you the chords for a song.  You couldn't practice chords easily, and as someone who knows nothing about playing the guitar, I was just completely lost and a bit frustrated.  It felt like I hit a ceiling and there didn't seem to be a way to improve.In Rocksmith 2014, the adaptive teaching system in the game gives you a set of tasks for each song to help you incrementally learn how to play it in real life.  It tells you what sections you want to practice, what chords you should learn, and just feels more like a teaching tool and less like a game.  The greatest improvement is that the riff-repeater is much like Rockband's riff-repeater, just infinitely looping a section and letting you adjust speed and difficulty on the fly.  No more loading, no more "do it five times to beat your score" gimmicks, just the ability to practice how you want, whenever you want.Yes, there are still goals and objectives, and the carrot on the stick is the various unlocks that the game will dole out to you as you meet these objectives, but if you're just here to learn how to play guitar (or more importantly, have fun playing some classic rocks songs), then Rocksmith 2014 is made for you.  I know I'm definitely looking forward to learning some of my favourite songs in the game.As an aside, the cable itself should be easy to find, especially if you can find a bargain bin copy of Rocksmith for one of the consoles.  I'd also recommend waiting for a sale on the first game and purchasing the disc import tool to give you instant access to 50 or so more songs to play - considering the price of the DLC, that's a very cheap way to bulk up your song library.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Ok a little back ground.  I've been playing guitar for a while and figured this would be fun.Here is why I am disappointed though:1.  You have to buy thier ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cable.  I have some studio gear that more than likely produces less latency than a dumb USB to 1/4" patch cable yet I can't use it unless:2.  In microphone mode I can select my audio gear, however Rocksmith WILL NOT accept a noise floor of zero.  I had to rub the strings while "muting" in calibration mode just to tell rocksmith that the noise floor isn't as high as they want it.  This parameter should be ajustable IMO.3.  When you do you mic mode you can't monitor your input.  I know they probably don't want a bunch of people complaining of feedback though so I guess I get it but again annoying.4.  There doesn't seem to be any way to bypass all the beginer stuff if you just want to play around and see how on point you are.IDK I get what they were going with here, and I do plan on snagging the cable to see if it's any better but the PC version should (in my opinion) take input from stuff other than the crappy cable they sell for this game.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												This game is f**king great! I love it to the max, The first day I got it I played it for 11 hours. Though I do not recommend  this to new players unless you are going to stick to the few really easy songs on it. I also think if you want to learn a song use tabs like http://www.songsterr.com/ . it is easy to remember then flashing notes coming at your screen. I think Rocksmith  is more for playing songs you have already learned, it is really fun. I don't play the arcade games much because I get enough practice with the fret board on my own, but some are cool like the zombie game thats like "The Typing Of The Dead" but with chords instead. There is few songs that I enjoy though, such as; The trooper - Iron Maiden, War Ensemble - Slayer, Heart Shaped Box - Nirvana, Pour Some Suger On Me - Def Leppard, Peace Of Mind - Boston, Knockin On Heavens door, Spirit Of The Radio - Rush, and Thuder Kiss '65 - White Zombie. there is also a lot of good DLC songs, like Iron Maiden songs, Megadeth songs, Pantera songs, etc. You also need a Rocksmith Real Tone Cable, which I have had mine from my Xbox Version. you can buy a Cable at a Gamestop/EB games I believe. Anyways, I think this is one of the greatest games I have ever played and I suggest getting it to the average guitar player, or skilled.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This game is simply amazing.  If you are looking for a quick way to learn the guitar, or if you are already skilled but want something to test you, or just want to make practice fun this game is for you.  The detailed system really gives you that one on one feeling of going to lessons, and the learn a song mode breakes down into segments and lets you learn it at your own pace by starting off slow and getting more difficult as you do better in the song, or if you are feeling really confident you can ramp the difficulty up to max from the very begging.  Also you can now use your computer as an amplafier and add any type of effect to make all kinds of different sounds.  As if all of these awsome features were not enough they have added the all new session mode making it easy to just jam out with a band that changes with you and pushes you to solo.  This game is a great buy for anyone with a guitar with any amount of skill.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												This is a great idea, performed only adeqately, with very limited diversity in song choices. They had the chance to make this game completely top notch but they settled for much less IMO and are really grubbing of the money about it too. I'm very disappointed that you cannot purchase all of the DLC at the advertised prices. Only the DLC specific to Rocksmith 2014. Otherwise you have to purchase the original Rocksmith ($29.99 right now on Steam and Amazon) and then another $10 tool to import the songs into Rocksmith 2014. Then you have to pay for the $3.00 song that you wanted in the first place. They are just sticking it in and twisting it, coming and going. They should have had some finger-picking and classical rock songs included but nothing like that. No rockabilly or hot rod sounding rock (like Commander Cody, Junior Brown, Johnny Cash). No real good blues rock either (Gary Moore, Seasick Steve and the like). I mean what artist wouldn't want millions of people learning their songs the correct way? How hard is it to sign up these artists? Well those are the main bad points about the game IMO. The good? Well it does a pretty good job of recognizing my guitar's notes for the most part although I have to repeat notes sometimes in the arcade games. Many of the songs are also very good and seem to be complete including multiple (dual) leads. There are tons of great sounds and effects for the guitar and lots made up specifically for the featured songs. You can slow the song without changing pitch with the riff repeater, allowing you to really zone in on tough licks. I also really like Session mode which really made me think a lot more about chord tones. There should have been some lessons for recognizing and utilizing them more effectively.I like the game. It's really more of a practice tool and its pretty effective as that. I have recommended it to friends and other musicians I know. Its just that I believe they could have done the game better and they probably will in the future ( I hope anyways)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												If you own an electric guitar or bass, own any of the supported systems, enjoy playing rock music, you MUST own this "game".  It is everything that Guitar Hero and Rock Band want to be, for those who can handle a real fretboard.  I do have just a few complaints... but I list them more as motivation for improvement (hopefully in patches, but at least in future versions)...A few interface navigation issues.  Generally "back" should return you to where you were.  That's not true 100% of the time.  Generally crossing between "Learn a Song" and "Score Attack" needs to have more attention devoted to it.  I think it works correctly if you access "Learn a Song" for a song from the Score Attack menu (IE, if I'm on "Some Song: Score Attack", select "Learn a Song", then use "Back", I'm at "Some Song: Score Attack"), but the inverse isn't true.  If I'm at "Some Song: Learn a Song", then select "Score Attack" and use "Back", I'm in the list of songs for Score Attack.Fine-tuning could be a hair easier.  I noticed on some songs when I got into Drop-D on my bass that I needed to tune the open D down a hair for the first three frets to be closer... don't know why... but I was failing hard on the 2nd-4th frets of the low string until I did. It may be different in other modes, but at least in Score attack, once it decides your string is in tune, it moves on, and there is either no way, or no easy way to keep measuring the one string before moving on.Lack of desktop UI optimization.  This is incredibly frustrating...  the game was obviously designed for a least-common-demoninator interface... so we have a UI that was meant for a simplistic game pad, even when using superior interface devices on a Windows or Mac PC. I think the best illustration is in sorting songs.  If you're on a device with a mouse (or touch for that matter), why not have drop-downs?  I tend to try to sort by tuning to see what to play next (I want to play them all, and don't want to retune between each song).  Tab, tab, tab, tab, tab, tab, "Crap, passed it", tab, tab, tab, tab, tab.....    WHY??  A search box would be great too...  we can certainly type a name if we're using console buttons remapped to a keyboard.  Oh... mission to do a particular song.... tab, tab, tab, tab, "crap, passed it", tab, tab, tab, tab, "Starts with 'B'? Great, I'm in the 'W's... ", up-arrow... hold.... hold.... hold...........    Search box...   click (search box entry), b, possibly a second letter in the title, click.  Done.   Even better.... if the mission is very specific, hyperlink the objective.  Actually, in most of the missions I can think of, you could give a button to go for it... or at least get closer (and that'd be even better for the consolers).  Next Mission: "Achieve 5% Mastery in Some Song", Press [whatever] to go to Learn a Song: Some Song.  Even with "play a new song" or "play x new songs", you could use that button to either randomly go to a new song, or open a list, filtered to unplayed songs.I could go one all day, but perhaps one more: Learn a Song, Riff Repeater, setting difficulty.  It'd be really helpul to have an easy way to tune the song's difficulty to matching the score attack levels (easy, medium, hard).  I figured out pretty quick that I need to try to get Platinum on Easy and Medium before using learn a song, because if I'm pretty good at the full studio arrangement, seeing the simpler arrangements screw me up.... but sometimes I'd like to use riff-repeater to nail the medium-level version (and on a few rare songs, the "easy" version).I've heard Zeppelin and Metallica are out because the record companies won't get on board. I'm guessing AC/DC is in the same boat. Here's some great DLC that may be easier to license:  Cake, lots of Cake...  SUPER bass lines, decent guitar riffs... I think that'd be fun stuff good starter pack may include "Hem of Your Garment" (awesome bass throughout, good rhythm through most of it... don't think there's a lead 6-string part in this one), "Sheep Go to Heaven" (something for everyone), and "Arco Arena" could be a really fun, short instrumental.  Ok... now here's something you're REALLY missing out on.  Music software for gamer geeks...    and NO JOCO?

I say buy RS14 and you should like it and if your a new player it will help you.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Pros ----- Using a real guitar.- Fun and educational.Cons ------ You need a proprietary cable to play. Ubisoft seem to have prevented third parties from providing cables.- Ubisoft have tied the game to Uplay accounts, trying to get you to have Steam AND Uplay accounts and DRM software installed (on top of the game!). It's confusing as to how much need it – some people imply you have to have a Uplay account, some that there are problems if you don’t sign in, others that you don’t need it at all. A good example of how confusing extra DRM makes playing a game. I don't know if they have eased off on this, but on my latest install I was able to skip the Uplay login with Esc and get in to the game, though you have to do this every time and ignore the server error messages. I don't agree with Ubisoft asking for personal data such as email addresses, and wanting you to set up more accounts and passwords.- Adverts; it slips songs to buy into songlists; opens browser tabs without permission, trying to sell stuff. It seems to be trying to milk you for money and data from the moment you click to play it. That leaves a bad taste in my mouth.Other ------- Some songs use different tunings, so if you don't want to regularly retune your guitar then the number of songs you'll play are far fewer than the listed number.- US accents in the game (narrator/helpguides).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
												I have only one problem with this game: Dynamic Difficulty.If you are a beginner, TURN THIS OFF, IT WILL MAKE YOU HATE YOURSELF.What Dynamic Difficulty does is, once you reach a certain level, it immediately bumps you up. For example, if you do OK on a 30% difficulty setting, even though you only played through it once and were decent,  the very next time it will be bumped to 50%, and I had no idea dynamic difficulty was on. I kept thinking to myself, "I've been practicing for weeks, why the ♥♥♥♥ am I getting worse and worse and worse?"And then I realized it's because the game was trying to bump me up to 100% difficulty within minutes. It will not wait for you no. I kept getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off and discouraged because of this stupid, pointless feature. I never wanted to play guitar again until I finally learned what this poinltess, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ feature was. I love the game, and now that I can actually move at my own speed it's a lot more fun  and easy. In short, dynamic difficulty is like an AP class, it will not wait for you to be caught up. If you can only play 20%, you'll do that once, get an okay performance, and then immediately the next time you play it will be changed to 40% difficulty, and if anyone here is like me, I can't learn 100% mastery in guitar in 3 hours from ground zero. Horrible pacing and just a god awful feature to be automatically turned on, especially for beginners.It'd be like after you beat a song on easy in guitar hero, the next song is medium, and then after that it's immediately switched to hard right afterwards. It's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Grade A game though, 9/10.

												First thing first - this is a game. If you are wondering if this game going to make you a guitarist, the short answer is no. I used to play drums, and tried to learn guitars and basses from friends before, this game helped me to learn bass to somewhat extent, but guitars - not so much. From my experiene, if you are experienced guitarist, this game will teach you the proper chords for some songs. For players with with some experience, you'll learn some more things. For noobs, well you'll learn some things, but learn from a real person to pick up things first, then come back to play this. This is a good "game" and fun to play. But don't expect to be something in 60 days.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Its aight..Okay on a serious note, i've been playing bass for over 10 years and even then I still felt like I was always learning something new. I never thought I would ever attempt to slap/pop, until I loaded up Higher Ground by RHCP. First run through almost impossible, but I kept at it and kept playing. Now I have such a basic concept that I can play through the song with no problems. Keep in mind, this game WILL NOT make you a God at guitar/bass your determination and willing to learn/practice will make you become a God. Switching it up now, i've actually used this game to learn guitar. I started a year ago and I can already tell a huge improvement which in theory keeps me pushing to become even better. This game CAN teach you to play if you've never picked up a guitar before, the amount of teaching videos and techniques are great for a beginner. I used to play around with tabs on Ultimate Guitar, but this game makes me enjoy playing bass even more than I already do!! If you'ce had any doubt in your mind, push that away and tell yourself you want to learn...then buy this game and keep at it. I believe in you :D

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												YOU HAVE TO GET THISits an awesome game that takes songs, techniques and lessons to any level you choose making it as easy or as hard as you choose. learning songs is the best part of it, because of the riff repeater. If you're struggling with a solo or a verse or even the whole song it lowers the difficulty for you or you can choose how much you want the difficulty to be. The other reason that learning songs on Rocksmith is the fact that it feels like you are playing in a band with all the music while you play. The percentage at the end just makes you want to get to 100%. Yes it does have some flaws like it doesnt always pick up notes unless the volume is at max (might just be my guitar) and the difficulty can go from easy to quite difficult on certain songs, but you can't do anything about that. But overall I love this game and have learnt more in a month of playing this than i  have over the past 3 months of youtube and guitar tabs. A MUST BUY FOR ANY GUITARIST!!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4
SummaryRocksmith 2014 is the absolute best way to learn to play guitar (and/or bass guitar). In my opinion, that makes it the best game ever!Background7 years of drums/percussion in middle and high school. 2 years of "ukelele band" in elementary school. Zero knowledge of guitar-playing -- I didn't even know if I was holding the pick right when I started Rocksmith. I've now logged ~300 hours between original Rocksmith and Rocksmith 2014. And I'm still loving it (just played multiplayer with a buddy for 2 hours tonight).Full ReviewOriginal Rocksmith was buggy and lacked a real "Riff Repeater", but I liked the focus on points and leveling -- it kept you trying to improve on specific sets of songs until you could perform them (at a certain level of skill).What sets Rocksmith 2014 apart is 1) the Riff Repeater, and 2) Session Mode.The "Riff Repeater" lets you pause a song, increase or decrease the difficulty and speed of sections of the song whenever/however you want. When you successfully play those parts on the speed/difficulty you chose, it can increase the difficulty and/or speed up automatically. This is perfect for learning new songs or working out the kinks in those tricky solos.Now, "Session Mode" could be sold as a $20 game in and of itself: you pick the key, tempo, chord progressions, and backing instruments and start jamming away. The notes in your key and current chord are highlighted; the backing instruments (and there's a wide selection to choose from) will accompany your play style/syncopation. It's great for working on solos, rhythms, etc. (I wish the beginner guitar player in the high school jazz band had access to this!)And Rocksmith 2014 keeps getting better! The "remastered" edition released recently includes tweaks to improve sorting and organizing your songs and favourites.How I recommend using it* Borrow your friend's electric guitar -- at least until you realize that you adore guitars. Then buy one on Craigslist.* Commit to "60 days of rocksmith": play at least 15 minutes every day for 60 days. Take videos of your progress!* After a few weeks, use your standard guitar to play "emulated bass", realize you adore bass, then buy one on Craigslist.* Buy amps, pedals, and mics to build your own music studio.* Get your friends to try Rocksmith, get hooked, buy their own guitars, and play multiplayer Rocksmith with them.* Find a decent drummer and -- presto! -- you've got a cover band. :D* World peace ensues.Tips* When I first tried to memorize a song above my skill level (Carry on my Wayward Son), I realized that my technique was counter-productive. Instead of memorizing, try to work on "sight reading" in Rocksmith first. (After completing my first "60 days of rocksmith", I set the "Level Up" difficulty to "faster".)* Once you've built your chops a little bit, you can more easily return and pick up those awesome songs you love!* To help with sight reading and chop-building, I usually choose "Nonstop play" mode, set to 20-30 minutes (often set to my faves).* Keep a few of the Rocksmith DLC in your Steam wishlist so that you can get alerted/emailed whenever there's a sale (which happens several times a year for about 40% off each song DLC). I usually pick up a few more DLC songs/song packs whenever there's a sale.* Setting a milestone (like a song you want to master) is a great way to stay committed. Also, doing the "60 days" with someone else can help you stay committed.* Lastly, I recommend picking up both original Rocksmith and the "Disc Import tool" because they let you play *most* of the original song selection and any original Rocksmith DLC you own inside Rocksmith 2014 (which gives you the better Riff Repeater).What I think they could do better* More Muse!!! (I need all the Muse!)

												It is a great improvement on the previous iteration, faster load times, more intuitive e fluid tabs, session mode its a great and fun way to pratice scales e harmonies, and the little arcade games offer a good fun way to pratice a few aspects of guitar playing. Unlike the previous Rocksmith which had a game mode, this one does not, so its more of a learning tool than a game. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This game is a big improvement on the original and fixes nearly all of the really annoying problems it had. I highly recommend this if you are into guitar or bass at all, beginner or advanced. The good:* Session mode is a huge addition that lets you improvise over a customizable band that reacts to what you are playing. This alone is worth the purchase price.* The tracklist and DLC so far is great and if you own Rocksmith you can import the 50 songs from that for $10* Large video library with lessons working from the very basics to more advanced techniques* Master mode will now gradually fade out notes from sections you do well in rather than throwing the entire song at you with no notes.* Riff repeater makes it easy to stop in the middle of a song and practice a section at any diffulty or speed you want. This is a HUGE improvement.* The new score attack with leaderboards is a lot of fun once you have a song down pretty well* The interface is, for the most part, much better.The bad:* The game seems much more forgiving on single notes now but can be very difficult to get chords to register completely throughout an entire song. Bends work fine on guitar but the game seems to have trouble recognizing them consistently on bass.* While the guitarcade games are better than the original's, they suffer from a lack of options and too much downtime after a loss to really be a great tool.* Still no way to just just study the tabs without playing the song* Career mode is gone and the game no longer plays back your performance after you've finished.

content:

My only complaint is that occasionally if i hit an incorrect note while playing a song, the game detects it as the right note, which makes the game think im better than i am, which doesnt help me learn.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Pros- Excellent music tool- Heaps of up to date songs... Even I found stuff I love, and my taste is... interesting!- Teaches you stuff you otherwise wouldn't want to study (I hate practising scales... normally)- Teaches you stuff you think is too hard (like scales) and makes it 'easy'- Easy to setup and use- Will help you if you know nothing about guitars- Will make you a good intermediary guitar player than any other tool- Really cool 'solo jamming' functionality providing you with improv practise- The multiplayer is really cool, just get another cable and have a great Jam without dragging an amp along :)Cons- Will make an hour go in 10 minutes, so you'll be late for work/school a lot- UPlay!!!!!!! update Steam... update Uplay.... update the game!!!!- Sometimes chords aren't picked up right, can be a bit fussy that way (that's being picky though, it's usually fine if you strum the chord right)- I'd like more feedback while I'm playing without going into score attack- The recommendations/goals... not sure I love them, but hey its' there to encourage.- the dynamic difficutly can sometimes be a bit annoying. I understand it's purpose, but I'd rather play the song right and slower than playing a note every 10 seconds sometimes (R U mine... I'm looking at you!!) :)- The lead arrangement for 'knocking on heavens door' is stupid :) Thoughts:- Even more seasoned players will get use out of this (I've played over 20 years)- There is no better guitar tool than this- I'm betting that the play list of cover bands will change because of this :)- Soon most songs from this game will become titles you aren't allowed to play when testing guitars at shops as they will all be played too much :)- Cover bands will have a more critical crowd as everyone will know every single note they're stuffing up :)- You can use the supplied cable for recording in other music programs; so get something a tool like Guitar Rig 5 (currently) and Sonar and start making music!!- Playing guitar will make you more attractive to women of the other sex :)- Don't blame me if you suck anyway after this :)

content:
Posted: April 4
SummaryRocksmith 2014 is the absolute best way to learn to play guitar (and/or bass guitar). In my opinion, that makes it the best game ever!Background7 years of drums/percussion in middle and high school. 2 years of "ukelele band" in elementary school. Zero knowledge of guitar-playing -- I didn't even know if I was holding the pick right when I started Rocksmith. I've now logged ~300 hours between original Rocksmith and Rocksmith 2014. And I'm still loving it (just played multiplayer with a buddy for 2 hours tonight).Full ReviewOriginal Rocksmith was buggy and lacked a real "Riff Repeater", but I liked the focus on points and leveling -- it kept you trying to improve on specific sets of songs until you could perform them (at a certain level of skill).What sets Rocksmith 2014 apart is 1) the Riff Repeater, and 2) Session Mode.The "Riff Repeater" lets you pause a song, increase or decrease the difficulty and speed of sections of the song whenever/however you want. When you successfully play those parts on the speed/difficulty you chose, it can increase the difficulty and/or speed up automatically. This is perfect for learning new songs or working out the kinks in those tricky solos.Now, "Session Mode" could be sold as a $20 game in and of itself: you pick the key, tempo, chord progressions, and backing instruments and start jamming away. The notes in your key and current chord are highlighted; the backing instruments (and there's a wide selection to choose from) will accompany your play style/syncopation. It's great for working on solos, rhythms, etc. (I wish the beginner guitar player in the high school jazz band had access to this!)And Rocksmith 2014 keeps getting better! The "remastered" edition released recently includes tweaks to improve sorting and organizing your songs and favourites.How I recommend using it* Borrow your friend's electric guitar -- at least until you realize that you adore guitars. Then buy one on Craigslist.* Commit to "60 days of rocksmith": play at least 15 minutes every day for 60 days. Take videos of your progress!* After a few weeks, use your standard guitar to play "emulated bass", realize you adore bass, then buy one on Craigslist.* Buy amps, pedals, and mics to build your own music studio.* Get your friends to try Rocksmith, get hooked, buy their own guitars, and play multiplayer Rocksmith with them.* Find a decent drummer and -- presto! -- you've got a cover band. :D* World peace ensues.Tips* When I first tried to memorize a song above my skill level (Carry on my Wayward Son), I realized that my technique was counter-productive. Instead of memorizing, try to work on "sight reading" in Rocksmith first. (After completing my first "60 days of rocksmith", I set the "Level Up" difficulty to "faster".)* Once you've built your chops a little bit, you can more easily return and pick up those awesome songs you love!* To help with sight reading and chop-building, I usually choose "Nonstop play" mode, set to 20-30 minutes (often set to my faves).* Keep a few of the Rocksmith DLC in your Steam wishlist so that you can get alerted/emailed whenever there's a sale (which happens several times a year for about 40% off each song DLC). I usually pick up a few more DLC songs/song packs whenever there's a sale.* Setting a milestone (like a song you want to master) is a great way to stay committed. Also, doing the "60 days" with someone else can help you stay committed.* Lastly, I recommend picking up both original Rocksmith and the "Disc Import tool" because they let you play *most* of the original song selection and any original Rocksmith DLC you own inside Rocksmith 2014 (which gives you the better Riff Repeater).What I think they could do better* More Muse!!! (I need all the Muse!)

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Rocksmith 2014 makes for mostly good times jamming on the guitar (there are some frustrating moments found due to a few poorly executed features and what seems to me a lack of several obvious features that should be included in the game). Many good ideas are implemented as practice games (in the style of classic arcade) to develop coordination and technique. While it is a much better game than the previous Rocksmith, it still leaves a lot to be desired in order to become an excellent practice helper and song tutor. Rocksmith 2014, while generally good, is currently just a good, not great, game for jamming on guitar and most likely improving one's guitar playing. However, it could become a great game with further development. Rocksmith 2014 is good, but hopefully there are better things to come in a future release such as having the game automatically adjusting your E standard tuned guitar to sound like it's in alternate tunings rather than having to manually tune your guitar for dropped or open or raised tunings in songs, being able to play technique games in alternate tunings rather than just E standard, menu navigation by playing certain notes such as little or big E strings to navigate up and down, an option that allows us to listen to the songs like a jukebox without playing along on guitar would be much appreciated, and I could go on and on with more suggestions!). With all of the talented people that worked on or consulted for this game it's a shame that there is so much more that could be done that is simply lacking from Rocksmith 2014. Could the plan perhaps be to hold out on features thus ensuring the purchase of a future installment? I would love to have a better iteration of this game, but please provide more features that seem obvious as much-needed inclusions!Rocksmith 2014 won't replace what you get in lessons from a great teacher. With the need for improvements and further development notwithstanding, this game is still worth picking up as it is the best thing available when it comes to a game that you can play with your own real guitar and most likely improving your guitar playing. It's mostly a good time (aside from frustrations encountered due to poorly thought-out features that need to be improved) especially considering that it will only set you back the cost of a couple lessons.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Yes - Buy this game. I had never played guitar or bass before, and spent about 200 hours in Rocksmith (1), loved it, but the improvements that have been made to Rocksmith 2014 are amazing! Everyone is talking about SESSION MODE, and Yes... it's awesome, but the best improvement in my opinion is the new way the game handles MASTER MODE. In the old game, if you learned to play the song correctly it unlocked MASTER MODE where you could then play the whole song without any visual cues. The problem is... I wasn't learning the song by memory - I was learning the song by watching the visual cues, and typically failed miserably during a MASTER MODE performance. In RS2014, MASTER MODE happens seemlessly while you play the song. As you do better at a certain section of music, the visual cues fade until they disappear, and reappear as you make mistakes. This method makes the jump from playing by visual to playing by memory so much easier. Also... multiplayer... good times aplenty. And a ton of DLC (new songs every Tuesday!)

												So far im really impressed by this product. content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Pros- Excellent music tool- Heaps of up to date songs... Even I found stuff I love, and my taste is... interesting!- Teaches you stuff you otherwise wouldn't want to study (I hate practising scales... normally)- Teaches you stuff you think is too hard (like scales) and makes it 'easy'- Easy to setup and use- Will help you if you know nothing about guitars- Will make you a good intermediary guitar player than any other tool- Really cool 'solo jamming' functionality providing you with improv practise- The multiplayer is really cool, just get another cable and have a great Jam without dragging an amp along :)Cons- Will make an hour go in 10 minutes, so you'll be late for work/school a lot- UPlay!!!!!!! update Steam... update Uplay.... update the game!!!!- Sometimes chords aren't picked up right, can be a bit fussy that way (that's being picky though, it's usually fine if you strum the chord right)- I'd like more feedback while I'm playing without going into score attack- The recommendations/goals... not sure I love them, but hey its' there to encourage.- the dynamic difficutly can sometimes be a bit annoying. I understand it's purpose, but I'd rather play the song right and slower than playing a note every 10 seconds sometimes (R U mine... I'm looking at you!!) :)- The lead arrangement for 'knocking on heavens door' is stupid :) Thoughts:- Even more seasoned players will get use out of this (I've played over 20 years)- There is no better guitar tool than this- I'm betting that the play list of cover bands will change because of this :)- Soon most songs from this game will become titles you aren't allowed to play when testing guitars at shops as they will all be played too much :)- Cover bands will have a more critical crowd as everyone will know every single note they're stuffing up :)- You can use the supplied cable for recording in other music programs; so get something a tool like Guitar Rig 5 (currently) and Sonar and start making music!!- Playing guitar will make you more attractive to women of the other sex :)- Don't blame me if you suck anyway after this :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												After playing this on consoles I picked it up on Steam for one reason.The Guitarcade.RS'14, as much as it wants you to believe it, is not a teacher, is not a replacement for a teacher, and will never be a teacher, while it's Lessons can be informative to the freshest of beginners the examples given in the lessons (placement of notes, what strings to play said note) can be very damaging to someone forming "new habits".What it is to me is a practice tool, if you have the basics of holding your guitar, fretting a few notes, or even a few chords, then Rocksmith 2014 is a great tool to help refine and poilish those a bit more, in an environment you are %100 comfortable in (IE; your own home!).Want to get the hang of shifting along the board? Fire up the Duck shooting minigame for 10-20 minutes a day.Want to speed up your Tremolo? Jump into the Hurdles event!Want to polish up your chords a little? Storm the castle and kill zombies, or fly through space blasting ships into oblivion!Bends? Temple of Bends will get you practicing your half-step and whole-step bends on a way you can see!Wanna run some Scales? Scale Racer has you covered there as you weave through traffic in an addictive way to remember scale patterns!It's not all rosey however!While this software can be a very, very useful tool, it gives no insight into "Music".There is absolutely no theory to learn from here, if you want to know what makes a chord, a chord... Rocksmith isn't gonna help you there.Want to learn notation? there's none to be had here which I think is this softwares biggest crime.This is for someone who owns/has owned a Guitar for a while, and is comfortable enough to use it, for the absolute beginner there are some pretty big pitfalls and chances to develop bad/hurtful habits if using RS and RS alone as a teaching aid.My biggest gripe is it's community, the UBI forums are filled by 3-5 people farming post counts, being down right rude, and giving bad/lazy information to people asking for it.This is a community of Gamers who own Guitars, not Guitarists who play Games.The DLC can be a touchy subject.Be it via pricing differences between platforms/Regions being seemingly random. to DLC plain out not showing.You will be also advertised original Rocksmith DLC inside the in-game store, (As it IS compatible with RS'14) yet Steam will not let you access it without owning the first game, this is apparently being looked at, but don't hold your breath it seems as they are focused only on the new consoles and their own store problems, The other formats don't even seem to be on the radar anymore.While I do recommend this product entirely, I do not recommend it as a Teaching aide, I recommend it as a Practice aide and urge anyone wanting it to check out reviews and videos from Users before running out to buy a new Guitar.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												This is great but not as a way to learn guitar. If a beginner plays this game in hopes of learning guitar, they will fall flat on their faces. There is little to no theory involved and you will end up "learning" how to use a guitar as a video game controller rather than an instrument. Don't get me wrong, this is a fun game to play if you can already play guitar as it is basically Guitar Hero, but that's all it is. If you really want to learn guitar, start with some Youtube tutorials. Learn some scales and fingering techniques first and most important, do not learn using the guitar hero method. You will be unable to play guitar without the help from the game and you'll sound like garbage outside of it. I really wish this game had more theory and exercises included; as the Guitarcade is not a proper way to learn.FInal Verdict: It's a game and you really won't learn much. 7.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												Rocksmith 2014 is a game where you learn how to play guitar through mini games, lessons, and more. The game was entirely built to be a learning tool. Here is my review of it.Positives:Within 3 days of owning the game, I learned the Penatomic Minor and Blues scales, and also how to play a song or two.Its lessons teach you how to play!You can learn songs such as Cemetary Gates, Thunderkiss '65, and even We are the Champions.If you buy the Physical copy from Amazon, you can get the game and the cable for $30.Session mode allows you to play on your own, and improvise your playing, letting you learn a bit without help.Negatives:Rocksmith 2014 was built entirely out of tablature, and not sheet music, so you won't learn how to play sheet music almost at all.If you buy the digital code, you'll most likely need to purchase the Realtone cable also, which is $30 on its own.The DLCs seem over priced to me, costing $3 for just ONE song!It's creator is Ubisoft, which isn't promising to most things (*cough cough* Assassin's Creed *cough cough*)Final Thoughts: If you have a guitar, and want to learn how to play, buy this, but know about the Negatives. This game does work as long as you want to learn tablature. This works, and I've been enjoying it so far.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Rocksmith 2014 is a learning tool/guitar hero-ish game where the main purpose is to give the user a better understanding on how to play el-guitar/bass while having fun. I've been playing el-guitar for a while now and I found it hard to understand tabs. I then tried out Rocksmith 2014 which have the guitar hero gameplay but you play with a real guitar. You get notes coming towards you with numbers on them which corresponds the frets and strings on your guitar. It's a bit hard to understand in the beginning, but you get used to it really fast. The game is really helpful and you can learn new techniques. You have to buy a real tone cable with the game which you plug into your PC and guitar. The gameplay works great and it's really relaxing and fun to play different rock and metal songs. There are a good amount of songs in the base game with different tuning, but have in mind that you can buy more songs as DLC. The game offers "learn a song" which is pick and play a song, session (you get to play on your own with a virtual band/ jamming) and arcade mode (different mini games you play with the guitar).I recommend this game to ppl who are new to guitar and ppl who just wanna relax and play songs without having trouble with tabs etc. A great game which offers a lot of fun!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Seriously just another game by 'Ubisoft'. Half completed as usual. TL;DR: Go buy yourself a guitar, and an amp and a cable. Teach yourself.Great game, great gameplay, teaches you things and does it all while you have fun.Only thing is... It is like EVERY other Ubisoft game. Full of bugs! You can learn and teach yourself with the internet in probably half the time, the only advantages this game has is that it keeps track of song completion, hit percentages and has mini games that are meant to teach you where strings/frets are, chords and so on. If you are new to guitar or have played it very little, this game might be alright for you, but if you have even learned half a song by yourself, STAY AWAY! The 'intuitive' scaling difficulty is annoying as hell, if you screw up just one little part, it could set the difficulty lower, even if you already know the song and attempt to continue playing normally. I am only writing this review (I had never intended to review this game) because today was the first time I have played the remaster. Before the game was okay, noticable bugs and such, but it was passable. After the remaster, sound randomly switches off, songs might or might not load, CTD's, everything that was there before is still there, only worse. Take it from me, you learn a lot more sitting in your chair with an acoustic and Ultimate Guitar pulled up on your browser than loading this trash up and restarting every 5 mins because you can no longer hear yourself strum. The only difference between this game and Assassins Creed is that Rocksmith has the very low potential of teaching you something. It taught me not to buy Ubisoft again.EDIT: After some thinking, I realised that if you are truely going to learn guitar, don't let this be your only method of learning. Using other methods in conjunction with this game may yeild okay results ;)

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												The original Rocksmith was completely stellar in terms of its feature set, song selection, techniques for teaching, and even going so far as to make teaching playing an instrument genuinely an enjoyable experience. It was pretty much the perfect guitar teaching game and offered a lot of fun new ways to enjoy playing music or developing skills for experienced guitaristsSomehow, Rocksmith 2014 managed to refine things that no one even realized were broken in the original title, then adds a whole slew of new features that makes this a esential purchase for anyone even remotely interested in the product. It DOES require the Rocksmith Real Tone Cable, which you can purchase on Amazon or in a lot of major retailers as a standalone device for a decent price. The Disc Import tool means you can also enjoy the songs from the old game in this new title, and there's already a lot of really solid and varied DLC. Definitely worth a purchase if you've already read through this much. I'd give this game more thumbs up if it was physically possible. All you need is a guitar with an output jack, and one of these http://www.amazon.com/Ubisoft-Rocksmith-Not-Machine-Specific-630570063043006306200/dp/B005OSFUZI

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												If you think learning how to play a guitar would be fun, this game is worth it.  However, you have to be prepare to learn how to play guitar, not how to play Rocksmith.  This is not easy, but if you are at all compelled to pick up the guitar, pick up Rocksmith.Giving this game a 'star' rating would be really tough.  What Ubisoft has managed to do with Rocksmith is amazing.  The ability to get the timing right between the guitar, the song, and the noteway is remarkable.  This technology has more potential than I can even begin to imagine.  I hope this continues to grow.In that respect, it's 5 stars all the way.  However, Rocksmith 2014 is not without some issues.First of all, the elephant in the room: UPlay.  I like the idea of a global leaderboard and the other community things that come with UPlay, but man, does UPlay suck.  Rocksmith is good enough, I'll forgive them, but I wouldn't buy another product that required UPlay.Somewhere between Rocksmith 1 and Rocksmith 2014 they messed up the tuner.  This is a really important part of the game.  Especially now with so many different tunings in the songlist.  The worst part about this is the lack of any real response from Ubisoft about this issue.  This literally drops 2 stars from the product.  I have to believe it's fixable though, if only Ubisoft would communicate what their plans are around this known bug.The UI is still poor.  Rocksmith 2014 has a much UI than it's predecessor, but it also couldn't have been worse.   Even really simple things like not properly doing key repeating in the riff repeater.  It still feels like a console UI ported to the PC, which generally means the UI sucks.Minus 1 more star for the poor UI, and we're down to 2/5 stars.  I really think both of these things can be fixed.   If you're in doubt, maybe wait to see if Ubisoft fixes the known issues.Keep Rockin!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												The original Rocksmith was completely stellar in terms of its feature set, song selection, techniques for teaching, and even going so far as to make teaching playing an instrument genuinely an enjoyable experience. It was pretty much the perfect guitar teaching game and offered a lot of fun new ways to enjoy playing music or developing skills for experienced guitaristsSomehow, Rocksmith 2014 managed to refine things that no one even realized were broken in the original title, then adds a whole slew of new features that makes this a esential purchase for anyone even remotely interested in the product. It DOES require the Rocksmith Real Tone Cable, which you can purchase on Amazon or in a lot of major retailers as a standalone device for a decent price. The Disc Import tool means you can also enjoy the songs from the old game in this new title, and there's already a lot of really solid and varied DLC. Definitely worth a purchase if you've already read through this much. I'd give this game more thumbs up if it was physically possible. All you need is a guitar with an output jack, and one of these http://www.amazon.com/Ubisoft-Rocksmith-Not-Machine-Specific-630570063043006306200/dp/B005OSFUZI
