content:
Posted: November 12, 2013
												Rocksmith 2014 does what the first one couldn't: be a useable tool to learn or improve your skills. The game has one of the best on disc soundtracks in a music game since the original Rock Band. Beginners will find this to be a fun supplement to other learning materials. Intermediate players will find introductions and tutorials to more advanced techniques. In terms of teaching, the game has very little to offer advanced players outside of the fun warmups/technique practice of guitarcade, the tabs that are the included songs and session mode. Still, session mode alone is can easily justify $15 of the price tag.Really what I enjoy the most about this is session mode, where you can put in a backup band that's quite customizable and have it adapt (to and extent) to what you play. It's the closest you'll get to jamming with a real band. My one gripe is that you can't record what you play without an external device, as Rocksmith overrides the computer's microphone to take input from the guitar.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												It is hard to call Rocksmith 2014 a game. I guess it technically runs just like most games, has achievements and features like most games and even has it's own mini-games. But you don't play it like a game; oddly enough you play it like an instrument. - Rocksmith 2014 has some fantastic lessons that explain in great detail what needs to be done to perform certain techniques. The videos and descriptions are great and the challenges are accurate to helping practise the technique. - Learn a song is great for doing just that. The games mastery system works well most of the time and is quite responsive to your own ability. Although, when it comes to DLC the game puts it down to 0 for some reason, even when you have high mastery of multiple other songs. I was also disappointed to find that you can't create your own playlists. I mean there is non stop play where you can choose the songs that will come up, just no decisions on specific order. - Session mode is definitely a highlight. As a musician myself studying Jazz, I found that a lot of what it teaches you is valuable improvising information. The band responds well and there are a decent amount of various alterations you can use to create what you want. The big downside here is that there is no recording mode, something that would be a big help to the game. Especially some kind of community system where players could rate each others riff or even song ideas. - Guitarcade is really fun while also great practise. Almost every learnable technique has it's own mini game that makes practising the technique fun. Each game also has it's own challenges that push you to better along with leaderboards so you can prove how good you are at each technique. Guitarcade also features score attack. Score attack is a mode somewhat similar to games like 'Rock Band' or 'Guitar Hero'. You choose a difficulty that gives you a specific amount of notes for the song and you get ranked on each phrase. If you miss too many notes in a phrase you get a strike. Three of those and you fail the song, and if you perfect every phrase, you get a gleaming 'Platinum'. Score attack also features leaderboards so you can attempt to be the top of your favourite songs.Overall Rocksmith 2014 is a fantastic learning experience. It has many features that can help you learn to play guitar or bass, just not completely. As any musician can tell you, you end up learning a lot just by practising, on your own and with others. While Rocksmith registers the notes you're playing, and teaches you about different techniques and concepts of playing, it can't recognize if you're really performing these techniques correctly. While you may be hitting every note accurately, there is a chance you could be doing yourself some serious harm just because the game can't see if you're doing it right. So, I recommend that anyone that is serious about learning guitar or bass should also seek out lessons from a professional along with learning from Rocksmith 2014.Score: 8.5Pros: - Session mode is great for teaching improvisation. - Leaderboards are a great motivator. - Guitarcade Mini-games are a fantastic way to practise techniques.Cons: - No recording in Session mode - Mastery for DLC gets reverted back to 0 - No creating your own playlists.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												So i've been playing guitar for a few years, mindlessly strumming chords and feeling like i was getting nowhere. I couldn't do anything impressive and only played to back up my singing. I got this game in the hope I could learn how to play guitar properly and play songs how they were meant to be played, strumming, picking and all. I was NOT dissappointed! The game is great! It really eases you into songs, starting with the most simple chords and riffs and building it up in a way that lets you feel comfortable but learn loads. Further more the % completed really makes you want to perfect a song and the suggested tasks is a great way to reach that 100%. For those that dont know once youve played a song through it suggests ways to improve, such as repeating specific riffs you didnt quite master, playing mini games to improve technique and suggesting lessons that might be useful. For me, playing along with the song playing is really useful too, helping you keep with the rhythm and the feel of the song. The part i've found difficult is the strumming, it tells you when to strum and which ones to accent but not really how, like up down up down sort of thing. However in the end you kind of just pick it up from listening to the song while playing. Since playing the game I have learnt a load new songs and feel im on the way to becoming a good guitarist, even if i am yet to 100% master a song. Cheers,Cal

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												First, I love Rocksmith 2014. I am certain that in large part because of it, I will not be one of the 74 out of 75 that give up guitar. I'm advancing rapidly (in my opinion) in just three weeks. RS14 has excellent feedback mechanisms to point out what is right and wrong about my playing. Riff Repeater allows me to focus on the first part of a song, 100% difficulty and 1% speed, until I get it (I wish to learn it right the first time through, not add bits and pieces here and there). While it has a scale game, I find it not very good for learning scales (maybe just me), so I augment my studies with the book "Fretboard Logic" in order to learn the logic of the fretboard. I recommend it. So I'd like to see much more done in the area of scale training. Yes, it can be picked up in Session Mode, but it will take a lot longer instead of having a focused scale training programming. Session Mode: I like this part of the program perhaps the best, because it's like having a band that can tolerate me at my current low level of playing. Very impressive. Riff Repeater: could use one improvement: the ability to control the transparency of the readout would be fantastic, as I often pause it to see what to do next with the finger placement, and sometimes the readout interferes with the process. I'm sure this will be fixed at some point. Once the Riff Repeater is set, it's function is somewhat unneeded until the next time one wishes to reset it. Right? Also, if paused, RR should be able to pick it up right from the point it was paused... it is very frustrating to have to wait for the music to pick up again, and learning could proceed much faster if this were implemented. I realized I'll never make the 60 day challenge. Everyone there has an Epiphone, and I don't plan on purchasing one. I purchased a few junk guitars so as to learn the mechanical/electrical aspects of guitar without ruining a nice Epiphone. :)  So I'm posting my weekly progress and insights on YouTube: "A guitar path using Rocksmith 2014: Week 1 of 52". Yeah, I'm sure it will sell a lot of copies of RS14 without the Epiphone. :) Overall, if you want to keep playing guitar without a major amount of frustration, get Rocksmith 2014. You'll be glad you did.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												"I play the guitar, I taught myself how to play the guitar, which was a bad decision, because I didn't know how to play it."-Mitch HedburgWhile half of the joy in teaching yourself how to play is in overcoming obstacles, along the way bad habits are formed and a narrow focus begins to form. For something as varied and complex as music, this is a fault. However, with Rocksmith, I've had great fun in playing songs I already knew, learning new songs I've liked, and even getting an appreciation for songs outside my usual tastes. The mini-games (Guitarcade) are great for daily exercises in building muscle memory and picking up good habits in terms of bends, chord formations, slides and picking.  You have to treat it like a 'learning tool' to get the most out of it, but if you already have a guitar on hand and forked over the cash for the 'Real-Tone' cable, then you're obviously aware of what you're getting into.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												While this game won't completly teach you how to play the guitar, it is a fantastic tool to aid in your mastery of those sweet steel strings.  This game has frustrated me to no end with its dynamic difficulty, but at the same time it's fantastic. For example: You'll be banging along knocking out notes, until NEW CHALLENGER APPROACHING! All of the sudden it'll throw a chord your way. You may never have seen this particular one before and at the speed you were at, it messed you all up and throws you totally off your groove. Well this thing isn't guitar hero and if you aren't already skilled at the guitar, can't be played as such. But if you slow down, use the Rift Repeater tool all day long and practice the fundementals more than you play, you'll be sitting pretty. TL;DR: This is a fantastic tool to motivate and gamify the learning of guitar. But it will not teach you all everything you need to know to be a master.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												I love my guitar, and sometimes I get bored. So one day I bought Rocksmith 2014. Ive spent over 100 hrs on Rocksmith (Original) and used it mainly because it gives you access to great effects to throw on your guitar. The game is great for learning as a begginner and moderate player. If you are just starting this game will try your patience. It's not a magical program that gives you techniques from the likes of Joe Satriani, Steve Vai, Dimebag Darrel, Dave Mustaine, Dan Donegan, Synyster Gates, and Andy James, HOWEVER....................... If you stick with it, and do the fundamental drill over and over again, you will progress at a decent pace. I recommend it if you are willing to put time into it. This is the only game where I can say I really didn't waste money, because it has a real life affect on the real world. ENJOY!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												So i've been playing guitar for a few years, mindlessly strumming chords and feeling like i was getting nowhere. I couldn't do anything impressive and only played to back up my singing. I got this game in the hope I could learn how to play guitar properly and play songs how they were meant to be played, strumming, picking and all. I was NOT dissappointed! The game is great! It really eases you into songs, starting with the most simple chords and riffs and building it up in a way that lets you feel comfortable but learn loads. Further more the % completed really makes you want to perfect a song and the suggested tasks is a great way to reach that 100%. For those that dont know once youve played a song through it suggests ways to improve, such as repeating specific riffs you didnt quite master, playing mini games to improve technique and suggesting lessons that might be useful. For me, playing along with the song playing is really useful too, helping you keep with the rhythm and the feel of the song. The part i've found difficult is the strumming, it tells you when to strum and which ones to accent but not really how, like up down up down sort of thing. However in the end you kind of just pick it up from listening to the song while playing. Since playing the game I have learnt a load new songs and feel im on the way to becoming a good guitarist, even if i am yet to 100% master a song. Cheers,Cal

												I love my guitar, and sometimes I get bored. So one day I bought Rocksmith 2014. Ive spent over 100 hrs on Rocksmith (Original) and used it mainly because it gives you access to great effects to throw on your guitar. The game is great for learning as a begginner and moderate player. If you are just starting this game will try your patience. It's not a magical program that gives you techniques from the likes of Joe Satriani, Steve Vai, Dimebag Darrel, Dave Mustaine, Dan Donegan, Synyster Gates, and Andy James, HOWEVER....................... If you stick with it, and do the fundamental drill over and over again, you will progress at a decent pace. I recommend it if you are willing to put time into it. This is the only game where I can say I really didn't waste money, because it has a real life affect on the real world. ENJOY!

content:
Posted: November 12, 2013
												Rocksmith 2014 does what the first one couldn't: be a useable tool to learn or improve your skills. The game has one of the best on disc soundtracks in a music game since the original Rock Band. Beginners will find this to be a fun supplement to other learning materials. Intermediate players will find introductions and tutorials to more advanced techniques. In terms of teaching, the game has very little to offer advanced players outside of the fun warmups/technique practice of guitarcade, the tabs that are the included songs and session mode. Still, session mode alone is can easily justify $15 of the price tag.Really what I enjoy the most about this is session mode, where you can put in a backup band that's quite customizable and have it adapt (to and extent) to what you play. It's the closest you'll get to jamming with a real band. My one gripe is that you can't record what you play without an external device, as Rocksmith overrides the computer's microphone to take input from the guitar.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												It is hard to call Rocksmith 2014 a game. I guess it technically runs just like most games, has achievements and features like most games and even has it's own mini-games. But you don't play it like a game; oddly enough you play it like an instrument. - Rocksmith 2014 has some fantastic lessons that explain in great detail what needs to be done to perform certain techniques. The videos and descriptions are great and the challenges are accurate to helping practise the technique. - Learn a song is great for doing just that. The games mastery system works well most of the time and is quite responsive to your own ability. Although, when it comes to DLC the game puts it down to 0 for some reason, even when you have high mastery of multiple other songs. I was also disappointed to find that you can't create your own playlists. I mean there is non stop play where you can choose the songs that will come up, just no decisions on specific order. - Session mode is definitely a highlight. As a musician myself studying Jazz, I found that a lot of what it teaches you is valuable improvising information. The band responds well and there are a decent amount of various alterations you can use to create what you want. The big downside here is that there is no recording mode, something that would be a big help to the game. Especially some kind of community system where players could rate each others riff or even song ideas. - Guitarcade is really fun while also great practise. Almost every learnable technique has it's own mini game that makes practising the technique fun. Each game also has it's own challenges that push you to better along with leaderboards so you can prove how good you are at each technique. Guitarcade also features score attack. Score attack is a mode somewhat similar to games like 'Rock Band' or 'Guitar Hero'. You choose a difficulty that gives you a specific amount of notes for the song and you get ranked on each phrase. If you miss too many notes in a phrase you get a strike. Three of those and you fail the song, and if you perfect every phrase, you get a gleaming 'Platinum'. Score attack also features leaderboards so you can attempt to be the top of your favourite songs.Overall Rocksmith 2014 is a fantastic learning experience. It has many features that can help you learn to play guitar or bass, just not completely. As any musician can tell you, you end up learning a lot just by practising, on your own and with others. While Rocksmith registers the notes you're playing, and teaches you about different techniques and concepts of playing, it can't recognize if you're really performing these techniques correctly. While you may be hitting every note accurately, there is a chance you could be doing yourself some serious harm just because the game can't see if you're doing it right. So, I recommend that anyone that is serious about learning guitar or bass should also seek out lessons from a professional along with learning from Rocksmith 2014.Score: 8.5Pros: - Session mode is great for teaching improvisation. - Leaderboards are a great motivator. - Guitarcade Mini-games are a fantastic way to practise techniques.Cons: - No recording in Session mode - Mastery for DLC gets reverted back to 0 - No creating your own playlists.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												A decent game that can run on just about any computer. It has lots of customization options and can help you learn new stuff really fast. The Riff Repeater function is really helpful as the game can vary in difficulty from a couple notes to the entire song 100% as if you were playing from a tab book. A good song selection is nice as are the minigames that test specific skills. However, the USB chord is pretty flimsy, so take care of it. Also you have to deal with the calibrating all the time. Furthermore--and most importantly--be sure to use a regular electric guitar with this. Acoustic-electrics don't work well in my experience, and regular acoustics require extra gear. Also changing the tuning for different songs can be frustrating if you have an electric guitar with a floating bridge (of course that's always true). So I say again: **Use a regular no-frills electric guitar to get the best experience.**

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Not as good as I expected.I think it might teach you the basics but overall if you want to learn to play guitar and play it well, it will take more than muscle memory contrary to what they advertise.While the game does set a good pace and teaches you playing techniques in a progressive manner, overall it might teach you bad habits.  You often won't be playing by ear and this is bad especially since the feedback is bad on certain occassion. There were times when just slapping on the strings would get you a pass and this is true especially when playing with chords. Bends, tremolo and hammer ons often do not register and it can become frustrating and you wind up doing more than you should. Overall, I think it's a nice introduction to complete beginners but I liken it to learning how to dance by using Dance Dance Revolution. I learned more from using Guitar Pro 6 rather than this product. Get a good guitar and amp. $60 for this software is too expensive especially when you will outgrow it a couple of months.

On every forum topic related to audio lag, they say; 'use analog audio !'1. It should work fine with any audio card2. IT STILL GIVES AUDIO LAGAnd to make things worse, when you adjust the lag settings in-game, you have to restart the game.You have to adjust the settings, close the game, open the game, wait for EVERY INTRO TO FINISH PLAYING, log in, and adjust the lag again because there is no setting that makes it work without any lag. It does mess up your sound completely though if you adjust it just right !Even if you CAN look past the lag, the game is still terrible.The guitar arcade could be kinda fun, the arcade games that let's you play scales are really usefull. Again, problem is, it doesn't work 100%, which really sucks if you want to try and get a high score (or just play at high speed).I guess people could learn a few basics using this, however it doesn't work for me. I started playing guitar (after playing guitar hero, which is why i want to like this game) 7 years ago, I learned song by learning tabs and using a tool called 'Guitar Pro' and watching youtube videos explaining the basics. I think it's way more logic to learn a song by learning to play it like it should be played, not on 'easy' mode playing 1/20 notes to get a 'feel' for the song. It just doesn't work for me. If you like playing guitar, don't learn it from this..If you like playing guitar games, play guitar hero.You're better of buying a guitar and a descent small amp for the same price AND guitar pro than this game.2/10 would not recommend.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												This is a fantastic tool to learn songs with, or to mess around in Session mode with a very customizable backing band. I'm less crazy about the "lessons" or minigames, but the core gameplay is extremely solid and tons of fun. Lessons from an outside source are necessary to really learn. The game does introduce techniques to you and has lesson videos, but they're somewhat shallow and don't really explain the "why" of things, nor can it critique your technique or correct bad habits. I highly recommend it for learning songs and as a practice aid, as long as you're coupling it with at least online tutorials, though actual lessons are always preferable. Yes, it requires Uplay, but it's pretty transparent. Once the new song format is figured out, community-built custom songs will make their way in again and unofficially expand the song library by a large amount.

												Hundreds of songs. Tons of fun. Dozens of bugs. (:It's a great game! And probably the best of its kind (there are not many alternatives though). Ubisoft did a great job! But did not quite polish it.I own a copy for PS4 and a copy for Mac/PC. Each one has it's own glitches. No profile synchronization (that is no progress synchronization), but I can stand it. No content/DLC synchronization!.. but yeah, everybody knows it. However, the most annoying are some regular issues that completely break gameplay. For instance, sometimes ejecting headphones leads to constant noise and you have to restart the game. Sometimes the game won't find your connected Real Tone Cable and you have to restart the game. From other point, some songs don't sound good. For example, The Rolling Stones' "Paint it, black" pedal effects seems almost muting the sound of my guitar (not always, though!). Of course, all that problems may be due to my OS (OS X 10.11.6, troubles on Mac? Seriously? What should I do? Re-install DirextX? oh wait, there is no DirectX! nor soundcard driver!), or my guitar (everybody knows that Rocksmith is very picky about it, btw I use Traveler Guitar ultra light electric to play the game).TLDR; It's a great game, but it feels like Ubisoft doesn't really strive for quality, but for profit. And the game really lacks of quality and ruins my game experience.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												TLDR: Just as I don't feel my guitar playing experience translates into this game environment, I find it unlikely that the game skills built up here can be translated back into the real world in any meaningful and sustained way while playing with other real musicians.  This might be a decent game, but if you want to learn to play guitar, start a band.  Be loud, anger your neighbors.  Go forth and melt faces.….If you've never picked up a guitar, then Rocksmith might be an interesting exercise in using a novel control scheme to interact with a game.  If you've spent any appreciable time with an actual guitar, this may very well be a frustrating experience.  So far it has been for me (an admittedly short time.)I imagine it to be similar to going through physical therapy and having to re-learn how to write or ride a bike after losing motor functions for some time.  None of my natural instinct for playing translates in this context.  Three minutes into playing, I felt as if i’d never picked up a guitar before and my close to 20 years of guitar playing might as well have been spent learning sign language.The issue was primarily with the small amount of lag between striking a note and hearing it.  This created uncertainty as to when *exactly* the computer was registering my playing and how that related to what I was seeing on screen.  Sometimes it is obvious, but in more complex passages this can create a very frustrating situation.  The visual interface inherits much of its design language from the video game world and while it looks visually interesting in a video or screenshot, the task of actually reading the interface while playing is overly complex and distracts from the task if you look at it from a teaching software perspective.  The camera movements are especially egregious.A few general nitpicks: There aren’t many songs included but of course you can augment your library with paid DLC.  The Ubisoft Uplay integration is as horrible and intrusive as it always is, so no surprises there.  The tuner software works with generous margins in order to work with the game, so you’ll have to re-tune every time you plug back into your amp.  After installation it crashed steam twice, but seems to have stabilized after the second reboot.If you're picking Rocksmith up to have a different take on a gaming challenge based around the archetypes set up by rock band and guitar hero, then you may just love it.  If you are looking for a way to learn how to actually play music, then I think you'd be better served finding an instructor or just starting a garage band and learning some songs.  (Hey, it worked for all of the bands who are getting paid to license their music in this game right?)

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												First of all, I want anyone reading this to know that I am nearing my 5th year of taking guitar tutoring, so I'm not a beginner at all (also, spelling might be off on the terms since I learn in French). The review is also for guitar, not bass. Now, onto the review.In a nutshell, this game horrible for experienced guitarists, but good for beginners.If you are a beginner, then this game is probably worth it if you can get it on sale and get the cable from somewhere else, but 60 euros for only the software is too expensive for me. The color coded chords are good for beginners since it helps them remember which chords to play. But for an experienced guitarist, the colored chords will only get in the way and mess up your technique.The accuracy of the chords played is... pretty bad to say the least. You can play 4th fret A chord when asked to play 5th fret B lol (and I know it's not my guitar, it's either the cable or the game). When playing 1st fret on any chord, it rarely registers my strum.The software is advertised as a learning program, but as a game it's very fun. I've seen someone on YouTube with ridiculous scores and flawless sequences, but then again that was their only learning tool since 4 fours of playing guitar (!!!! yes I know it's pretty crazy).In the end, this software is not a learning program, it is a game for inexperienced beginners who don't want to learn seriously. I do not reccomend this game, as a tutor (or self tutoring if you really want to commit) will teach you far more in a manner that will let you use his methods OUTSIDE OF HIS LESSONS, unlike Rocksmith in which you will be relying on the screen to play.And of course, you can do both if you want to. I'm not your mum.

content:
Posted: January 13
												I taught myself how to play and consider myself an intermediate player.  The display of the fretting on-screen is upside down from actual tablature which makes it very difficult to understand if you already have experience.  As the  song shifts up and down the fretboard, the display animates the shift in a very disorienting way which I cannot follow even when playing songs I already know.  I used two different guitars and could not find a setup that worked nicely with the software.  I tried all sorts of combinations of pick-up selections and tone adjustments and still had a difficult time making it through the tutorials.  When playing certain games, it will show you what it thinks you're playing.  With a perfect tune, certain notes would be fine and others would be one to two steps off.  I spent too much time trying to circumvent the quirks in this game and no time learning anything about playing a guitar.

												it's funny how this game tells you to play relaxed but then frustrates the hell out of me by not counting 30% of the notes that i play right. it was great at first and i was improving quickly. i have had the shifting lesson go from 100% on 45 notes down to getting 70% or less on 33 notes. i set the practice track to play all 51 notes and have the lesson at 94% complete but my accuracy keeps getting lower and lower. the last time i did it today i had 64% despite knowing that i'm hitting all of right notes. yesterday i was in the 80% up and down. most of the wrong notes keep coming from the 12th, 11th, and 10th fret notes. i just went through the lesson video and at the part where you're supposed to hit 12, 11, 10, 9, 3, 4, 5 it counted the 3, 4, 5 as right but i played 4, 5, 6. at the part that it says to play the 7th fret i was on the 6th and the game said i'm on the 8th. i've been playing about 8 days, more than 1 hour the first few days and less than that the other days because this is annoying the crap out of me. i'm scared i'm going to break my strings because the game is making me think i'm not strumming loud enough for the notes to properly register. i honestly do not see how i can ever recommend this to anyone.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												This game has been out for a while but is still full of bugs.  Starting from the very first screen the main account selection screen there are visual bugs when you select between accounts.  It requires an internet connection to some main server for a single player game.  The usb device itself is buggy.  Booting my computer with the device plugged in makes my mouse and keyboard so laggy I can't get past the login screen.  Fine, so I have to keep it unplugged during a reboot.  When it isn't dragging down my whole system, it is often not detected and you have to restart the game.  The loading screens are not able to be skipped so being forced to restart the game over and over and not skip those screens is infuriating.  Even when the usb device does work it is not good at detecting what notes you hit.  You can play nothing and it will count slightly vibrating strings as a perfect score. This entire game is a fraud.  Having this game on steam makes steam less credible.

Posted: June 28, 2016
												I have been playing electric guitar for about four years now and I thought that this would be a fun way to spice up my practive routine. and it is very fun but it caters more to the guitar hero fans than musicians. Their approach to learning also encourages mistakes as the note imput is sloppy. The game starts you at full speed and minimal notes instead of starting you at a lower speed with all of the notes and chords. I know that beginners may be intimidated by all the information of a full song, but some of these songs are very beginner friendly for this type of learning. I know that in riff mode you can slow it down to half speed but it should be done at the first attempt in order to really learn a song. also for those looking to learn guitar beware, you can have very very sloppy technique and still get a 100 %. you are better off finding a good teacher. Note I used an MIA standard Telecaster.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Very slow and confusing install.  Took a LONG time as it needs steam and updates. I have a slow internet connection and it took most of the afternoon.  I already played guitar, so it came pretty easy. But I would say this is more geared for newbies. However the songs go well into very advanced.  What's nice is they start at newbie level and as you progress they increase in difficulty.  I don't use it as "a game" I use it to learn some of my fav songs.  The interpretations really appear to sound SPOT ON.  It's a lot more fun practicing (even beginner levels) when you have the actual band playing with you.  So you sound good no matter what.  I have a hard time practicing every day and this really makes that happen and fun.  I find I'm playing for hours a day rather than occationally every couple weeks or months.   Once you get use to steam, and uplay and this program it all is pretty well designed. (just confusing at first with how they interrelate.  Execution, load time and logistics are quite well done. WIth a few exceptions.  There needs to be a  PAUSE and STEP FORWARD AND BACK in the riff tracker. You can pause. But then the menu covers the display. And when you unpause the area of the song you have selected restarts from the beginning.  (Doesn't continue on).  I often have to pause and try and look at what is coming and finger through it a few times before tackingly it at even the slowest speed.  At present, it doesn't allow this easily.  Next in Jam Session mode which is over all very nice... the chord changes need to be displayed. The band can make changes in the more advanced settings, but they don't show you when or what the band has changed to.  It just displays the initial "KEY" like "A".I display of what bar we're on would also be nice. So if playing the 12 bar blues progression we can see what bar the band is on. This is such a great and powerful feature (Session mode) but is lacking in things that would be really simple to add. The program already knows, it only needs to display that info to the player.   Last recommendation is the "arcade games" are a bit lame. They seem more random note rather than combinations of 3-4 note licks that would be more musical.  I find the arcade the least helpful part of the package. (I no longer use it).  The scales display is nice with the notes of the scale and the chord notes signified as solids.  Also - I didn't pay attention to their MISSIONS at first.  I later found if you do the missions it helps "teach" you your way around the program and how to use the features.  This rather manditory since the program comes with no real documentation of any value.  The holiday sale (going on as I type this) is on target... I've been waiting and I just spent around 115.00 in extra DLC.  (all the songs I like).  Of course I had to also buy RS1 on sale and the disc import tool.  I bought them on Mac (when they were never available for Mac) and I didn't have to download RS1 (why I won't want it) just the songs.  I then downloaded the disc import tool. (found on the RS2014 promo and buy page) 9.95.  It took about 30 minutes to download.  I then didn't know how to run it.  And found you don't!  Once you have it and RS1 on steam the songs just APPEARED IN MY LIBRARY!    All (well almost all) the RS1 songs (no clapton about 5 aren't included) and all the content I buy now appears in my library.  I have 175.00 invested so far. (software and DLC) I feel it's well worth it. I use to pay 30.00 per hour for guitar lessons.  Once I left I'd often forget what I was suppose to work on.  So I video taped my lessons. Still 3 lessons were 90.00. 6 lessons cost more than what I have invested in this program and I can GO BACK and see the lessons over and over again.  I'm using this on my Imac and LOVE IT.  I recommend it highly.  Ron in MI.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												The good:  Rocksmith 2014 is a good way to get started and if you don't have the money to get an amp right away, this is a  great alternative with all the profiling they have done it's actually fun to design and play a custom tone.  The guitarcade makes drills fun by adding a game element to it.The bad:  learning a song via flying notes that don't pause for you is not a good way to learn.  This is guitar hero with a real guitar, but you can't really learn a cover song at your own pace.  Honestly, sites like songsterr and ultimate guitar are far superior for learning a cover tune.  If you already know a cover, playing along with Rocksmith is kinda fun.  Also, just make a shortcut to Rocksmith.ini on your desktop; you're going to be in and out of that file a lot if you discover the signal from your guitar to the computer doesn't work right away.  Overall: 2/5

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												I have no idea what the Playstation or Xbox versions of this simulator are like, but I paid a total of £70 for the pc version, and I feel utterly cheated. The game itself is very well set out and sets things out in a very simple, easy-to-use manner (although the idiotic Californian narrator is highly irritating, but that's personal perferance) and Rocksmith should be a good tool for budding guitarists, even ones as musically inept as myself.    The reason I do not recommend this simulator however is due to the game-destroying glitches that Ubisoft still haven't tackled. Chiefly, the tone of my guitar tends to disappear after half an hour of playing, leaving a dull, dry sound in its wake. This cannot be remedied by anything other than restarting the whole thing, only for it to happen again. That hardly matters though, as typically the game will freeze shortly after this occurance.  I'd like to say this was a wise investment for any aspiring musicians, but frankly I'm going for the traditional way to learn guitar; the only thing to worry about with actual teachers are mental breakdowns, not handing them 70 quid and have them freeze and have to be restarted.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Firstly - unlike a lot of reviewers, I have not had any experience playing guitar before.  Seems people get much more benefit if they have already have lessons / experience, and use Rocksmith to hone / improve skills.At this point I really don't know if I would recommend it or not (stupid Steam forcing one or the other).... Im still slogging through it, but I think the whole game is just schitzophrenic - trying to be a game and a teacher, and getting neither right.  IF YOU HAVE AN ACOUSTIC GUITAR - DO NOT BOTHER.... THE GAME IS NEARLY UNPLAYABLE!!!!!!  Feedback problems, poor pickup of chords and notes, constant re-tuning means this game SUCKS.  YOU NEED HEADPHONES .... Dont bother trying an acoustic without them.The game needs a "Getting Started" guide or some sort of walk through to help people work out how to best use the software.  When you start the game up you just randomly pick from a menu of stuff to do with some guitar picks to try and suggest what areas you should work on.  NOTHING in the way of guidance beyond that.  Getting set up was a BIG hassle (and it still isnt 100% or even 90%) with my acoustic guitar with a piezo pickup .... Lag issues and getting my guitar to even work with it was a pain, but once that was sorted, it started out being a fun way to learn.  I tried the lessons, which quickly became frustrating because the software wont always pick up notes correctly, and the lag means I had to adjust when to strum.  The "suggested" lessons are all over the place in order... going from some basic stuff straight to slides and stuff, before even teaching a single chord, scale, or even picking any string other than bottom E.  In other words, the "difficulty" ordering of the software is TERRIBLY inconsistent.  Once you do get some basics right, it jumps in difficulty to something stupidly hard (compared to the last run through) with symbols that arent explained, progressions that you arent prepared for, to name a few issues.The songs are the same.  Sure - each song says what lessons you should have covered, but even with that done, their suggested difficulty path was all over the place, adding in symbols that just arent covered.  As a song's difficulty ramps up, it does so in ridiculous amounts, and it doesnt adjust well to the problems you may be having until you suffer through the song, then it starts to figure what strings and notes you have trouble with.  The arcade games SUCK.  They obviously spent too much time on the "arcade" aspect of making them look like 8bit games with a lot of unnecessary, unskipable screens, and not enough on note detection, learning aspects, and difficulty streamlining.  When it says my bottom E string is in tune, the games will consistently miss detect a fret and tell me Im on the wrong one.  I had to DE TUNE the string lower than the true note in order to make it half playable.  Then once you bomb out of a game, you have to put up with screens you cant skip through before you are able to start the game again.  You spend more time in those screens than actually playing.Overall I can see some potential in the idea, but they have a lot of room for improvement.  If you think this program will teach you to play from scratch, then be prepared for a long, slow, frustrating experience as you jump from area to area trying to figure out what you are supposed to be doing, and in what order.  Once you start getting used to the game, search around for stuff, click on things, it starts to become clearer as to how it works.  A very different approach to what friends have suggested in the past for learning guitar (learning chords, tabs, etc).  I definitely wouldnt say better though.Pros:+ um.... it sorta teaches you to play guitar+ gives you something to do when you are really bored+ a fair list of songs (see the Cons)Cons:- PITA to set up, especially with an acoustic.  You have to keep the game volume right down, or use headphones cause the body of the guitar picks up sound from the speakers- Lag issues / timing is off- Note detection sucks (at least with my acoustic) and is hit and miss, meaning lessons are hard(er) to complete- No "How to Get Started" guide or tour- Most songs are crap and not popular, which makes playing them much harder if you dont know them at all (I had to buy a couple I knew just so I had something familiar to work with, and funny enough, I do much better with them)- The lessons are terrible and just repeat over and over, except maybe to slow down the speed, they give you no guidance as to what you are doing wrong beyone the basics (wrong fret / string)- The lessons are all over the shop - why the HELL would beginner lessons be looking to do bends, slides, hammers, etc when they cant even play all the strings and pick the right frets properly- I have a special HATE for the bends... I just about have to snap my strings for the game to recognise them.  Not to mention that a beginner probably wouldnt have the finger strength to do them (I put my hand over the top of the fretboard and managed to get a couple of bends to register because I have better strength with a squeezing motion rather than a pushing motion)- Even though the game knows what you have covered and (theoretically) what you have struggled with, it still just throws you right in the deep end with a song, forgetting all that "learning" it supposedly does.  It doesnt filter out stuff you havent tackled well, until you let it fail repeatedly- Arcade games with unskipable and unnecessary screens is just stupid- When repeating a lesson it doesnt even give you enough pause to get ready inbetween.  Can be probably changed in settings, but something so basic shouldnt have to be done manually when it should figure you are struggling- After each session with Rocksmith, Im left feeling frustrated and dissapointed with my (lack of) progress.   Oh, they give you a token "pat on the back" for a decent run, but after awhile its just so much hot air- With not detection issues it is impossible to complete some lessonsI give it a 5 out of 10.... borderline.  Im still trying to hold my frustration in check and slog through it, but it is NOT FUN.  I dont expect learning guitar to be a blast, but this game does little to make it feel more enjoyable.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												A game like "Rocksmith" is truly a difficult thing to review. There are so many different concepts to music and to how people want to evolve their talent that no one opinion will do justice to this game. It functions and provides a great distraction to rote training, but it honestly is not the best tool around.For starters, "Rocksmith 2014" does not have the best tutorial around. I guess with the rise of the YouTube era, everything is taught to you by a quick video. You are then tasked with plucking strings and holding frets without any knowledge of why. The game neglects to go farther into music theory, as well. I suppose a quick lesson on tremolos will do, but that honestly isn't going to elevate your skills farther.The next musical sin comes from the explanation of notes. If you play bass, you might as well skip this game. The game constantly badgers you to check the note book, but then only includes that option for lead guitar. Even then, there is no further elaboration on how to properly place your fingers or what the root of each note stems from.There are no detailed looks into intervals, timing, self-tuning or note patterns. You simply are told to place your finger on fret 5 and play it on the first string. It would be nice to know that is an A Note, but I suppose that little detail is irrelevant.If your only interest in music is learning how to play a very select assortment of songs, then sure; "Rocksmith 2014" will allow you to play those songs. You will more than likely sound sloppy and have no form, but man can you rock out to 'You Really Got Me'.In the end, I haven't spent eons with the game. The only reason I got it was because I figured it would be a good supplement to my regular music lessons. It hasn't failed in getting me more interested in playing, but it definitely has held me back from growing as a musician.I suppose this game is really only intended for those who are bored with their instrument or want to augment their playing into a really standard and unskilled manner. You will be better served calling up a good teacher and getting yourself taught the basics of music theory.5/10

												I have played in many bands and with different instruments. And I own this and the first rocksmith game on xbox. And the main consern is lag! LAG LAG LAG! None of these two are playable, I regret buying both! I have an exellent computer and I use it to reherse and record alot of music, and I can play the best games on it.  But this game has a serious latency problem! From the time you play a chord or tone, to the time it is registered is ridiculous... I also own every rockband and guitar hero game made, and when these also have their latency problems. When you push a button you get a more instant result, and you can play to the music. The rocksmith games does simply not work yet... I hope to play a game like this 5 years into the future when latency is no longer an issue. If you play a chord you want a reaction. What if you had this kind of lag in f.ex Ducktales, you would push jump, and fall into the pit before the duck would know to jump... Bad, bad... :(

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												In short I'd say this game is a poor tool for learning to play but worth picking up if you can get in on sale and can also get an inpuit without purchasing the unneccasary cable.I picked Rocksmith up from Humble just to try it out of curiosity, I've played for about 10 years or so with various bands but I struggle with the game. I find the layout so needlessly confusing I spend 99% of my effort trying to figure out what it wants me to play. Honestly a decent tab is so much easier to follow for me personally.Also the audio quality isn't great and the calibration can be hit and miss. At times it lags like hell and just ignores input which makes it unpolayble at times. The menus are fiddly and non skippable intro bugs me. I'd reccomend a tutor > various youtube channels > online resources > rocksmith in that order for someone looking to learn, but for the right person I'm sure it could be a decent supplement to other lessons.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												Alright, SO, recently I made a review for Rocksmith when I was fuming and incoherent. I now figured out what happened to my game. Also note I have spent about 400$ on Ubisoft products (Rocksmith Guitar, 2 Cables, Software, and bought DLC) **I bought DLC as recently as 3 months ago.So I've been playing for 1-2 years now and have been downloading CDLC over that time, at random. Whenever I wanted a different song I would just go and pick it up. I developed quite the list of songs and was happy with what I had for probably the past 4-5 months without getting more cdlc. Recently, October 14th 2016 to be exact, I start up rocksmith remastered with the patcher; note this had worked fine for the past 2 weeks (with the updated patcher). Hitting enter to get into the accounts screen I immediately notice there is only one account, it says "F U C KYOU" instead of any of my account names. I logged into the account (at first I thought I might have been hacked or something) and none of the dlc that I had bought were there or my cldc; I launched with the patcher. After a repeated attpemt, I figured UBISOFT had done this to make sure people were buying their DLC instead of downloading CDLC. I really don't care (even though it's unprofessional at best) because if you delete the game (which deletes all the cdlc and reinstall) it gives you the game back and your dlc. Which I've done, and probably will still continue to play, but this is really cheap because most of the cdlc I downloaded was USER content. Why should USER content have the same copyright problems as your specific DLC content? Any way I don't care but I thought people should know about this before buying the game. It's an incredible tool but this is not fair to a repeat customer like myself.My last review was really bad, just swearing and incoherent. I needed to fix that so I deleted the last one lol. It's best to wait a few days when your mad at a game. ANNNDDD all I'm saying is this could've been handled a THOUSAND different ways, but they chose to put "F U C KYOU" without a warning.This is ANNECDOTAL at this point I didn't screen cap because I was fuming mad, the game works fine now and I'm not about to try it again.

												Rocksmith 2014 is great - that, is, if you can stand it freezing and crashing every 10 minutes.  It freezes when I try to access any lesson, it sometimes freezes at the home screen, it crashes for no reason, and sometimes, I can't even get it to start without rebooting my computer, sometimes twice.It's unfortunate, considering how improved the format and game play is from the original Rocksmith.
